newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: EU urges Jakarta to act on Timor human rights.
newsitem.headline: EU urges Jakarta to act on Timor human rights.

text.p: The European Union on Saturday repeated calls for Indonesia to improve its human rights record in the disputed former Portuguese colony of East Timor.

In a declaration issued at a summit in Dublin, the 15-member bloc "calls upon the Indonesian government to adopt early measures to improve the human rights situation in East Timor (and) hopes that talks under the auspices of the U.N. will lead to substantial progress towards a resolution."
Last month Indonesia's EU ambassador told Europe to keep out of the East Timor issue and warned that European measures there could have "grave repercussions".

The EU has proposed giving East Timor development aid, which the Irish have said would focus on projects such as building primary schools. But Indonesia said recently this could jeopardize current tripartite talks on East Timor between Portugal, Indonesia and the United Nations.

"The Council welcomes initiatives to improve the situation and living conditions of the East Timorese people, and reaffirms its support for all efforts which can contribute to a fair, comprehensive and internationally acceptable solution..," the EU declaration said.

East Timor, which has a population of some 900,000, was invaded by Indonesia in 1975 and annexed by Jakarta a year later in an act not recognised by the U.N., which still regards Lisbon as the territory's administering power.
